{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3287147,"name":"Nick Foote","username":"Footie","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/footie/{size}/218325_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-17T20:24:45.936Z","cooked":"

Like most teams, we’ve got rollers to pick up rings and shoot them, and from our initial prototyping and v1 robot, we’re getting a large amount of static charge building up on the rollers, especially the ones that run nearest the carpet (like balloons rubbed on your head). We’ve had minor static issues on shooter wheels before, but never this bad. From what I understand, most of the electronics can handle a potential shock, but the motor controllers are NOT one of those, and can easily fry. This concerns me greatly.

I’m not an electrical engineer but my understanding is that this is made worse because the rollers are between two polycarb plates, and the charge has no where to go but into our fingers when we touch it, or possible a motor controller if it folds up in a way as to get it close.

I have a couple ideas, but I don’t actually know if they would work, or if they’re FRC legal.

First one is just a steel bead chain from the chassis that hits the carpet. This doesn’t help with the shooter rollers exactly, but with the chassis building up static in general (like from the swerve, or the bumpers being really low to the carpet, but not touching). I’m fairly certain this is legal, and at the very least, won’t hurt.

Secondly, is on our rollers. When prototyping, we had dead axle rollers, so we just taped wire from the mounting bolts and ran it back to the metal table they were on. This didn’t completely eliminate the issue, but it seemed to help.

image1629×911 136 KB

Would the same principle apply where, we just need something conductive to connect the roller mounts back to the metal of the chassis assembly? I was thinking of doing it with some of that copper tape to keep it low profile. This would be pretty simple, however, I have no idea if it’s legal, or would even help (and might even come off and get wrapped up in the rollers).

Then on the more drastic side, we could put steel brushes on the rollers (like how a laser printer works) to pull the excess charge off.

Or do we just get dryer sheets and wipe down the rollers between matches?

Electricity is so weird, how do you guys deal with this issue, or did we just build this incorrectly?

iirc 118 in 2022 had similar static issues, and they solved it by electrically connecting their chassis and dropping a wire to the carpet
but it’s been a while so i might be wrong

Our team had constant static issues at the start of the 2023 season, using McMaster silicone over carbon fiber rollers. We found that Pledge, the furniture polish, eliminated all of our static build up almost immediately. We used it every 2-3 matches. Not a permanent fix, but a very effective temporary solution!

image187×654 37.1 KB

both. Last year we applied it every 2-3 matches, because we needed a ton of grip from those rollers. This year, we are using silicone rollers again, and only need to apply it after 20-30 minutes of running
